description: A man accused of killing a Bridgeton woman told police he blacked out and beat and choked the victim into unconsciousness after an argument turned physical. Patrick A. Spann, 39, also of Bridgeton, is charged with murder in the death of Tracy L. DuBois, 37, whose body was found along the banks of the Cohansey River on May 22. He allegedly killed DuBois at a vacant...
text:
A man accused of killing a Bridgeton woman told police he blacked out and beat
and choked the victim into unconsciousness after an argument turned physical.

Patrick A. Spann, 39, also of Bridgeton, is charged with murder in the death
of Tracy L. DuBois, 37, whose body was found along the banks of the Cohansey
River on May 22.

He allegedly killed DuBois at a vacant warehouse on Grove Street in Bridgeton
following an argument over "another male," according to his criminal
complaint.

Two witnesses told police that Spann and DuBois, who were described by police
as acquaintances, argued in the warehouse on the night of May 21 and that the
dispute turned violent.

The witnesses then left the warehouse for the night, they told investigators.

As the fight continued, Spann "described himself as blacking out, beating and
choking the victim until she became unconscious," according to his affidavit
of probable cause.

Spann told police he then left the warehouse and later returned, when he
dragged her body across the property to the nearby riverbank.

He also admitted finding the two witnesses in downtown Bridgeton the next
morning and asking them to help him move the body "to conceal it further."

Acting on a tip, police recovered the victim's body that morning and arrested
Spann the same day.

When officers approached him, his hands were covered in blood, according to
the affidavit. He also had two cuts to his left hand, which was described as
"excessively swollen," and had blood on his clothing, police said.

In addition to murder, Spann was charged with desecration of human remains,
tampering with physical evidence, obstruction and theft. He allegedly took the
victim's purse after the killing.

Spann remains in Cumberland County Jail pending a detention hearing, which is
slated for June 9.

DuBois was born in Bridgeton and was a Bridgeton High School graduate,
according to her obituary.

Matt Gray, NJ Advance Media, mgray @njadvancemedia.com.

title: Man charged in killing told police he blacked out
html:
A man accused of killing a Bridgeton woman told police he blacked out and beat and choked the victim into unconsciousness after an argument turned physical.

Patrick A. Spann, 39, also of Bridgeton, is charged with murder in the death of Tracy L. DuBois, 37, whose body was found along the banks of the Cohansey River on May 22.

He allegedly killed DuBois at a vacant warehouse on Grove Street in Bridgeton following an argument over "another male," according to his criminal complaint.

Two witnesses told police that Spann and DuBois, who were described by police as acquaintances, argued in the warehouse on the night of May 21 and that the dispute turned violent.

The witnesses then left the warehouse for the night, they told investigators.

As the fight continued, Spann "described himself as blacking out, beating and choking the victim until she became unconscious," according to his affidavit of probable cause.

Spann told police he then left the warehouse and later returned, when he dragged her body across the property to the nearby riverbank.

He also admitted finding the two witnesses in downtown Bridgeton the next morning and asking them to help him move the body "to conceal it further."

Acting on a tip, police recovered the victim's body that morning and arrested Spann the same day.

When officers approached him, his hands were covered in blood, according to the affidavit. He also had two cuts to his left hand, which was described as "excessively swollen," and had blood on his clothing, police said.

In addition to murder, Spann was charged with desecration of human remains, tampering with physical evidence, obstruction and theft. He allegedly took the victim's purse after the killing.

Spann remains in Cumberland County Jail pending a detention hearing, which is slated for June 9.

DuBois was born in Bridgeton and was a Bridgeton High School graduate, according to her obituary.

Matt Gray, NJ Advance Media, mgray @njadvancemedia.com.
